description: For over a decade, scientists have made extraordinary progress on the long-held dream of fabricating an entire cell from nonliving molecules and materials.
title: The promise of synthetic cells

description: The Australian parliament will conduct a national inquiry into the dangers of "forever chemicals."
title: What exactly are 'forever chemicals'—and can we move beyond them?

description: Sub-Saharan Africa has a vast amount of uncultivated, arable land—about 2 million km2, accounting for about 50% of the global total. This land is a critical habitat for many animal species, including birds.
title: Bird species are disappearing at an alarming rate in Kenya, study finds

description: Search and rescue for missing persons is always challenging for the specialist recovery teams involved, regardless of the environment they're working in.
title: Bayesian yacht disaster: How specialist search and rescue teams work underwater

description: So much science news this week. It's like a torrential deluge of information bursting explosively through a levee of ignorance. Who built that levee, anyway? How did they get that through the legislature? Anyway, of the hundreds of stories we reported this week, here are capsules of three interesting ones. Two of them involve bugs.
title: Saturday Citations: Tarantulas and their homies; how mosquitoes find you; black holes not mysterious at all

description: To introduce quantum networks into the marketplace, engineers must overcome the fragility of entangled states in a fiber cable and ensure the efficiency of signal delivery. Now, scientists at Qunnect Inc. in Brooklyn, New York, have taken a large step forward by operating just such a network under the streets of New York City.
title: Test of a prototype quantum internet runs under New York City for half a month

description: The ceramic produced in Prof. Igor Lubomirsky's lab at the Weizmann Institute of Science seemed too good to be true. It belongs to a class of materials that are the backbone of many essential technologies but that unfortunately also create an environmental problem because they usually contain lead, which is highly toxic.
title: Nontoxic ceramic could replace lead-based electronic components

description: Giant black holes in the centers of galaxies like our own Milky Way are known to occasionally munch on nearby stars.
title: Watch a star get destroyed by a supermassive black hole in the first simulation of its kind

description: On a remote tallgrass prairie in North Dakota, a secretive orchid pokes up from the ground. You'll only find it if you know where to look.
title: A rare orchid survives on a few tracts of prairie. Researchers want to learn its secrets

description: Icelandic authorities said Friday that a second fissure had formed on the southwestern Reykjanes peninsula, but volcanic activity had decreased after lava started spewing forth for the sixth time in the region since December.
title: Iceland's volcanic eruption slows as lava flows from second fissure

description: My new article, "Quantum Entanglement of Optical Photons: The First Experiment, 1964–67," is intended to convey the spirit of a small research project that reaches into uncharted territory. The article breaks with tradition, as it offers a first-person account of the strategy and challenges of the experiment, as well as an interpretation of the final result and its significance. In this guest editorial, I will introduce the subject and also attempt to illuminate the question "What is a paradox?"
title: Researcher explores how you can stretch your mind to grasp quantum entanglement

description: With months until crunch talks on the world's first binding treaty on plastic pollution, experts are meeting in Bangkok to discuss financing options and problematic plastics.
title: Experts meet as final global plastic treaty talks near

description: The detention in Greenland of anti-whaling campaigner Paul Watson pending possible extradition to Japan has turned the spotlight on the widely condemned practice of hunting whales.
title: Whaling: why the practice will not go away
